fields.label: A lower core cost (administrative or support-function expenses not tied to a specific program)  means a nonprofit is more efficient.
We fund nonprofits when they seek money for organizational development that may not be  directly related to a program.
Changing nonprofit partners frequently creates competition amongst them, pushing them to  be more efficient.
We encourage our nonprofit partners to create an operating surplus and transfer the surplus  to reserves.
We rarely have a conversation with nonprofits partners to reduce core costs at the proposal stage.
We encourage our nonprofit partners to find alternative sources for covering their core costs rather  than asking us to increase our
A  nonprofit’s relationship with other credible funders is an important selection criterion for us.
Nonprofits are able to do well even in the absence of organisational development.
We typically support programmes that show results within an annual funding cycle.
Most nonprofits do not have the capabilities to manage reserves.
We proactively introduce our nonprofit partners to other funders.
The majority of our funding goes to nonprofit partners whom we have supported for a long period  of time.

fields.description: benefit all sections of the community equally.
fields.label: A special focus on marginalised communities is not necessary, a nonprofit’s initiatives will typically
The leadership composition does not matter as long as the nonprofit organisation is working on a  credible issue.
Organisational development funding does not contribute to social impact.
